Graphical abstract The use of ‘Click Reaction’ for Cu(I) catalyzed azide–alkyne cycloaddition (CuAAC) has emerged as one of the most powerful tools for the synthesis of library of organic molecules having a wide range of applications. The approach is highly stereoselective that involves the formation of 1,4–disubstituted 1,2,3–triazole derivatives by the combination of diverse structural entities in the presence of Cu(I) as catalyst. There are numerous synthetic Cu (I) complexes with different ligands bound in diverse molecular framework with potential to act as catalyst to stitch organic azide to alkyne producing 1,4-di-substituted products. This review emphasizes on those versatile Cu (I) complexes having tailoring capability similar to those available commercially. Keywords Azide-alkyne cycloaddition CuAAC Click chemistry Cu (I) catalyst Triazole formation Catalysis 1 Introduction CuAAC reaction has emerged as versatile and conducive gizmo for the stereoselective organic synthesis popularly referred to as ‘Click’synthesis’ [1]. In 2001, Sharpless re-defined click reactions as a set of reactions that must be modular, facile, rapid, using benign solvents, is wide in scope, producing high yield and generate inoffensive byproducts with stereospecific product isolation [2–8]. The extensivity on click reactions in literature involves metal catalyzed 1,3–dipolar cycloadditions [9–12], thiol–ene reaction [13–15], Diel’s alder cycloadditions [16–18], Michael addition [19,20]etc. Among these set of click series of reactions, CuAAC reaction has grabbed universal attention with its extensive employment especially in material science [21–25] and drug discovery [26–33]. Rolf Huisgen, in 1963, discovered an uncatalyzed thermal 1,3–dipolar cycloaddition reaction of organic azides with alkynes, and is commonly referred to as ‘Huisgen 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition reaction’ [34] resulting into generation of the mixture of 1,4 and 1,5–triazole products [35]. The thermal reaction between terminal alkynes and organic azides was performed at high temperature for a long duration and is shown in Fig. 1 . However, in 2001, the utility of Cu(I) by Sharpless et.al in catalytic amounts, drastically improved the rate of reaction even when carried out under relatively mild conditions with perfect regio–selectivity, as shown in Fig. 2 . The isolation of 1,4–disubstituted–1,2,3–triazole as the only product is considered as one among the greatest achievements in synthetic chemistry [36,37]. The mechanistic route of catalytic action of copper (I), was projected by Sharpless and Fokin [1,8]in 2001, is shown in Fig. 3 (Route–I) which involves the binding of Cu(I) to ≡CH carbon, thereby locking the stereochemistry to single position product. DFT studies later on supported the proposal, in 2005, which predicted an activation energy barrier of 23.7 kcal/mol for the formation of product from copper (I)–acetylide which is cut short by the use of Cu(I) to 14.9 kcal/mol for the formation of six–membered intermediate in comparison to the barrier of 25.7 kcal/mol for an uncatalyzed reaction [38]. Later on, Fokin and Finn revised the mechanistic cycle with proposition of addition of azide to Cu(I)–acetylide preferably occurs when another molecule of copper(I) species is available which suggested mechanism involving two copper nuclei, one bonded via sigma–and another through π–complexation. The interaction of copper(I) with π–system of terminal alkyne decreases the electron density over sp–hybridized alkynyl carbons facilitating deprotonation at terminal carbon to form sigma-bond with another copper atom and then the attack of azide, as shown in Fig. 3, (Route–II) to form bridged dicopper μ–alkenylidene intermediate (1) [39–42]. This dinuclear intermediate is thermodynamically more stable than the ring strained mononuclear six–membered intermediate (2) formed from mononuclear mechanistic pathway. The structural characterization of dinuclear copper moiety as intermediate was analyzed by electrospray ionization mass spectroscopy [43–47]. Since discovery, the worldwide popularity of CuAAC among researchers from different disciplines can be attributed to the formation of an aromatic heterocyclic that is stable and chemically inert to oxidation, reduction and hydrolysis thereby imparting it utility in fields of biochemistry, polymer chemistry, chemo-sensing, drug discovery [48–65]etc. Alternatively, the reaction of azides and terminal alkynes has been found to be catalyzed by other metal ions such as Ni(II) [66], Pt(II) [66], Pd(II) [67], Ir(I) [68,69] as well as Ru(II) [70]. However, in terms of efficiency correlated to the time of reaction, temperature, yield and area of application, none of these has any comparison with copper (I)–catalyzed process [71–74]. In spite of availability of library of review articles [75–78], the comparative study involving the methodological advancements in Cu(I)-catalytic framework as a potential catalyst is a need of time. 2 Copper as a source in CuAAC reactions The literature studies reveal various types of copper sources that provide Cu (I) as active species to acts as catalyst in specific reaction conditions. According to the nature of catalytic precursor, the different types of catalytic systems are classified and introduced in the following sections. 2.1 Cu(II) catalytic systems 2.1.1 Cu(II) salt and reducing agent Copper(II) salts are relatively more stable and have ease of access and can be easily reduced in situ to copper(I) to act as great source of catalyst [79–83]. CuSO4.5H2O along with sodium ascorbate is the most widely used in the category of Cu(II) salts. The upgradation of Huisgen cycloaddition using Cu(I) catalytic system under benign reaction conditions brought revolutionary change in the organic synthesis. The insitu generation of reduced Cu(I) species, from CuSO4.5H2O by sodium ascorbate resulted in solvent mixture of water and alcohol (methanol, ethanol or butanol) [2–6]. The use of organic solvent promotes the solubility of organic hydrophobic reactants and aqueous medium ensures green approach of synthesis through CuAAC reaction [84–86]. The composition of solvent mixture depends upon the nature of substrate and ultimately affects the percentage yield of product. In a typical reaction between benzylazide and phenyl propargyl ether, as shown in Fig. 4 , resulted into 1,4–disubstituted 1,2,3–triazole derivative with a yield of 91% in the presence of CuSO4.5H2O and sodium ascorbate (1:5 mol%) after stirring at room temperature in a capped scintillation vial. The regiochemistry of triazole formed was confirmed by X–ray crystallographic studies [8]. To avoid the use of organic solvents and following the concept of green chemistry approach, CuAAC reactions have been conducted successfully in the presence of quaternary ammonium salts as phase transfer catalyst in combination with CuSO4.5H2O and sodium ascorbate in water with excellent yield of triazoles [87,88]. The organic synthesis involving phase transfer catalysis is generally allowed in water, an eco-friendly solvent [89]. Phase transfer catalyst facilitates the reaction by migration of reactants from organic phase to aqueous medium and vice versa in order to reduce or eliminate the need of very toxic and expensive organic solvents [90]. In CuAAC reaction, this approach has been generally employed in one pot synthesis of 1,2,3-triazoles by taking terminal alkyne, organic halide (aliphatic or aromatic) and azide salt in a common vessel in the presence of phase transfer catalyst along with copper catalyst in aqueous medium. The process involves in situ generation of organic azides in the reaction mixture followed by cycloaddition reaction. This feature also enhances the importance of this method, as the handling of organic azides is not very safe due to their poisonous and hazardous nature [91]. Moreover, this multistep reaction performed in one pot is significant both economically as well as environmentally as it avoids the separation and purification of intermediates [92]. Considering the green chemistry approach of organic synthesis in mind, Praveena et al. in 2015 has reported a reaction of 2–chloro–(3–chloromethyl) quinoline with terminal alkyne using NaN3, KI in water at room temperature along with tetrabutylammonium bromide salt as phase transfer catalyst and CuSO4.5H2O, sodium ascorbate as a source of copper (I) as shown in Fig. 5 . The reaction was performed with a strategy that involved one pot CuAAC followed by azidation in water under mild reaction conditions. An increase in the rate of reaction was observed with the addition of 6 mol% of tetrabutylammonium bromide as phase transfer catalyst. The reaction took 8 min for its completion instead of 30 min when no additive was there in reaction mixture and yielded 93% of product. The heterocyclic compound formed as product is used as potential cytotoxic agent. Following this approach, the research group synthesized a library of such pharmacophores and studied their cytotoxic effects on various types of cancer cells [93]. Besides the nature of catalyst, the product yield also depends upon the reaction conditions as well as solvent. A report by S. Pal and research group described the synthesis of 1,2,3–triazole–nimesulide hybrid, an anticancer agent. The reaction was performed as copper catalyzed cycloaddition of 4-azido nimesulide with phenylacetylene in the presence of CuSO4.5H2O and sodium ascorbate using a variety of solvents at room temperature as shown in Fig. 6 and observed the effect of change of solvent on final yield of product [94]. It is worthy to express that outcome of reaction was excellent (95% in 5 min) in water. Although, PEG-400 is used as a biodegradable polymeric solvent in organic synthesis, but was associated with very poor yield in comparison to the yield in water under same reaction conditions. In comparison to aqueous medium, the reaction was not completed in 5 min in PEG-400 and required 180 min to reach to completion with 89% of desired product i.e. less output as well as slow rate of reaction. Similarly, the reaction rate and results in DMF and CH3CN were not very appreciable. Output of cycloaddition has also been found to get affected with the nature of substituents on alkyne and azide, in a particular solvent and catalytic conditions [95,96]. The biomedical applications for CuAAC requires the organo-molecules need to be protected from certain toxic molecules produced from excess of copper ions and oxygen in the presence of sodium ascorbate [97,98]. These highly virulent molecules that can cause significant alteration in the protein structure by oxidation [99] as well as polymer degradation [100]. Therefore, for reduction of Cu (II) to Cu (I), a water soluble compound tris(2–carboxyethyl)phosphine [101–105]is an effective alternate to the use of sodium ascorbate. It complexes with copper (I) and inhibits the formation of toxic molecules. 2.1.2 Cu (II) salt without reducing agent Inspite of using combination of Cu (II) salt and reducing agent as catalyst, Cu(OAc)2 has been used effectively without any external reducing agent in pure water as well as water/alcohol mixtures. In 2009, L. Zhu and his research group performed Cu(OAc)2 catalyzed reaction of propargyl alcohol with 2–picolylazide in alcoholic media without the addition of any other reducing agent as shown in Fig. 7 . The reaction was conducted by using 5 mol% of Cu(OAc)2 in t–BuOH, yielding more than 95% of product within 1–2 min of reaction initiation. The spectroscopic analysis confirmed the reduction of Cu (II) to Cu (I) by oxidation of alcohol to carbonyl compounds. The high reactivity of 2–picolylazide molecule was attributed to its ability to form chelate with copper (I) ions. During CuAAC, homocoupling of alkynes can also reduce Cu(OAc)2 to Cu(OAc) [106]. In addition to these, a different technique to convert Cu (II) to Cu (I) is photo reduction i.e. reduction in the presence of UV–vis light using a suitable photo-initiator instead of reducing agents [107–110]. The research contribution of Yagci et.al group with this protocol involved use of copper(II) chloride along with PMDETA ligand, where the irradiation with ultraviolet (UV) light promoted reduction of Cu (II) to Cu (I) by transfer of electron from π-system of ligand. Another mode of reduction process involved the use of photoinitiator that absorbed UV light and produced radicals as very reactive intermediates that facilitated the reduction of Cu (II) to Cu (I) graphically shown in Fig. 8 [111,112]. One of the studies on light induced CuAAC involved use of Fullerene (C60) joined with linear polystyrene as a photosensitizer and CuSO4.2H2O as a source of copper. The cycloaddition reaction got completed in 2 h in UV-radiations and resulted into 95−98% of the product [113]. Chen et.al made use of [4-(2-hydroxyethoxy)phenyl-(2-hydroxy-2-propyl)ketone] as a source of radical intermediate to get Cu (I) from Cu (II) (Fig. 9 ) and a triazole based ligand for photoclick azide alkyne cycloaddition reaction [114]. To expand the utility of photoindued catalysis, in 2019, B. Yin and co-workers conducted a light induced CuAAC reaction followed by aza-Michael addition in a multicomponent one pot system using CuCl2/Me6TREN as catalyst and isopropylthioxanthone as photoinitiator. Combination of ligand and photoinitiator caused rate as well as yield enhancement. 1.7 mol% of catalyst produced 97% of product in only 20min [115]. Moreover, photoinduced CuAAC reactions are highly controlled, where rate of reaction can be managed with the alteration in exposure time and intensity of light [116]. Due to these properties, this strategy of organic synthesis has remarkable utility in biochemistry and material science involving the use of numerous types of ligands and photoinitiators [117–120]. 2.2 Cu (I) salts 2.2.1 Cu (I) salts/Co-ordination complexes as catalyst In order to minimize the use of reducing agents, direct use of Cu (I) salts have been preferred, but the stability of Cu (I) in a given solvent is always questionable. It generally gets oxidized into Cu (II), a stable oxidation state. To minimize the oxidation of Cu (I) must be attached to bulky organic substituents as ligands have been preferred as catalytic species and the compounds such as [CuBr(PPh3)3], [CuI(P(OEt)3)], [CuF(PPh3)3], [Cu(MeCN)4]PF6 etc. are the most commonly used potential catalysts. Table 1 summarizes the effect of reaction conditions on the yield of product of cycloaddition of alkyne and azide by using different copper (I) salts as catalyst. 2.2.2 Macromolecule coupled Cu (I) ions The trend of modifications in the use of Cu (I) catalyst involved the development and use of various Cu (I) frameworks that can be recovered after completion of reaction. Polymer coupled Cu (I) catalysts have been proved effective in this direction for facilitated removal of residual catalyst after CuAAC reaction by complexation with strong polydentate ligands or by simple precipitation method. Therefore, the chelating ligands like EDTA (ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) [128], DDC (diethyldithiocarbamate) [129] have been successively used along with catalytic system for the removal of excess of Cu(I) by chelation. The coupling of Cu (I) ions with polymeric systems protects them from oxidation into more stable Cu (II) ions as well as prevent the generation of certain unwanted molecules that can harm biomolecules, if conducted in bioconjugation. A polyisobutylene coupled Cu (I) catalyst has been found to conduct alkyne-azide cycloaddition reaction effectively in a solvent mixture of heptane and ethanol at 90 °C. The removal and recovery of catalyst was carried out by precipitation method and reused in subsequent reactions [130]. Cu (I) ions coupled with dendrimer (Fig. 10 ) is another type of protected catalytic system. The strategy of using dendrimer also reduces the amount of catalyst upto 0.1 mol% instead of 5−10 mol% in case of water–soluble combination, CuSO4.5H2O with sodium ascorbate. Moreover, these water-soluble dendrimers can be easily removed from product after completion of reaction by solvent extraction method without any decomposition and reused many times [131]. 2.3 Nanostructured Cu-catalysts Metal nanoparticles differ in the properties from other molecular or atomic systems owing to the large surface area of nanosized particles. The use of copper-nanoparticles (Cu–NPs) as catalyst have a set of merits over other Cu (I) complexes i.e. a] large surface area that ensure more number of active catalytic sites per unit area, b] acceleration of reaction process without the use of any other additive or ligand and c] ease of separation from product ensures less contamination of product and reusability [132,133]. In 2005, Orgueira and Rothenberg conducted the first CuAAC reaction using copper nanoparticles and is shown in Fig. 11 . The amine hydrochloride salt of alkyne was used by Orgueira in order to increase the solubility of Cu-NPs in t–BuOH/H2O mixture [134], whereas Rothenberg and his research group used tetraoctylammonium ion for the stabilization of nanometric copper clusters, without any additives at room temperature [135]. In 2013, A. Pathigoolla and co-workers used in situ generated Cu-NPs by reduction of cupric sulphate with hydrazine hydrate and carried out cycloaddition of terminal alkynes with aromatic azides at room temperature under solvent free conditions [136]. The studies indicate that the supported metal nanoparticles (Heterogeneous catalytic systems) are more robust and efficient catalytic systems in comparison to unsupported counterpart. The essential advantage of support is the prevention of aggregation of particles and universal control over their dispersion and morphology. In addition, the loading of metal can be reduced and the use of heterogeneous catalytic systems makes an easy path for their separation from product and reusability [137]. Literature is enriched with a variety of support materials like carbon substances, polymeric substrates and inorganic solids that have been employed in copper catalyzed azide–alkyne cycloaddition reactions, as summarized in Table 2 . 2.3.1 Cu-NPs over carbonaceous compounds The activated carbon–based materials, with large surface area and inert behavior, have capability to act as good support for Cu_NPs. The modifications at the surface of these materials with carboxyl and hydroxyl functionalized groups have provided the better binding sites for metal particles generating a perfect metal embedded catalytic system. Cu–NPs anchored over activated charcoal, carbon nanotubes and graphene oxide have excellent catalytic qualities in alkyne-azide cycloaddition reactions. A research report by B. H. Lipshutz and B. R. Taft described the synthesis and use of catalytic system having nanoparticles of Cu (I) over activated wood charcoal. This catalytic assembly have found utility in CuAAC reaction of several kinds of alkynes and benzyl azide at 60ᴼC in dioxane and resulted into 1,2,3-triazoles with good to excellent yields. After completion of reaction, the catalyst was separated by filtration, washed with water and reused thrice without any change in catalytic activity [138]. The use of carbon support has been extended to carbon nanotube material impregnated with Cu–NPs and its use produced yield upto 95% at ambient temperature conditions [139]. The choice of appropriate pore size over cylindrical shaped carbon nanotubes enabled an effective dispersion of nanoparticles and prevents them from aggregation. The activity of catalyst depends upon extent of dispersion, diameter of nanotubes and binding of metal particles at the surface of support material. However, a high cost of synthesis of these catalytic materials limits their use. Among carbon–based materials, graphene and graphene oxide are found as good support for nanoparticles. Graphene can be obtained from graphite and has remarkable chemical, thermal, electrical and mechanical properties whereas graphene oxide can be generated by oxidation of graphene using various oxidizing conditions. Graphene oxide (GO), with honeycomb like structure provides optimal surface area for nanosized metal ions and also prevents their collapsing. Graphene oxide coupled with Cu–NPs has been used in various CuAAC reactions and has good catalytic activity in solution as well as in molten form [140]. The significant improvements in the catalytic activity have been observed with graphene modified with nitrogen moieties. Introduction of nitrogen atoms in graphene layers help in easy attachment of Cu–NPs [141] (entries 1–3 in Table 2). 2.3.2 Polymers as support for Cu–NPs The catalytic systems with Cu–NPs over covalently crosslinked polymeric materials have advantage of being recycled and reused. The polystyrene based materials have been modified with dimethylaminomethyl moiety in its structure and loaded with Cu–NPs has an excellent catalytic activity in CuAAC reaction. Dimethylaminomethyl group acts as good ligand for metal ions and at the same time it acts as base to accelerate the cycloaddition reaction by abstraction of proton from the terminal alkyne to form Cu-acetylide intermediate. Subsequently, a large number of polymeric substrates with nitrogen ligands were developed and used as support [142,143]. To follow the greener approach, the use of biopolymers like cellulose, alginates, chitosan etc. as support for nanoparticles has been tested successfully. In 2014, P. V. Chavan et.al group have developed a catalytic system having cuprous iodide nanoparticles supported over cellulose and introduced in one pot CuAAC reaction for the synthesis of 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazoles. An excellent yield of 96% was obtained in water as solvent at 70 °C using sodium azide, terminal alkyne and alkyl halide in common vessel [144]. In 2019, Lignocellulose impregnated with copper sulphate was applied in CuAAC reaction and yielded 86% in MeOH/H2O in the presence of sodium ascorbate with an easy recoverability of catalytic moiety. The recovered catalytic system was reused five times with minor loss in catalytic activity [145] (entry 4 in Table 2). 2.3.3 Inorganic solid supports Inorganic solids having oxygen, nitrogen or phosphorous like atoms can hold metal or metal ions effectively by binding through these atoms [146,147].Based upon this strategy, various inorganic materials like silica, alumina, certain magnetic materials etc. have been used to support nanoparticles of Cu (I/II) ions. These inorganic solids having Cu (I/II) ions over their surface that possess excellent catalytic potential for CuAAC reactions with the advantage of being recovered after the completion of reaction by simple separation techniques and are reusable. In a cycloaddition reaction between an azide and alkyne, CuI mounted over silica has been used as catalyst at room temperature and resulted into 93 % of desired product with good recyclability [148]. To improve the ease of separation of catalyst from product, a catalytic assembly having silica and Cu–NPs composite, mounted over Fe3O4 was synthesized and used in CuAAC reaction. The paramagnetic nature of Fe3O4 promoted ease in the removal of catalyst by magnetic separation after the completion of reaction. The yield of product was also noticeable 149. A literature study has also reported alumina supported copper ions as recoverable catalysts for CuAAC reaction [150]. B.C. Ranu et.al group synthesized alumina-based copper catalyst by stirring CuSO4.5H2O with basic Al2O3 for 2 h at room temperature. The purified catalyst was used in one pot synthesis of triazole derivative by the reaction of benzyl halide, phenylacetylene and sodium azide under ball-milling technique (mechanical grinding) without any additive and solvent. Best results were obtained by using 10 mol% of catalyst and ball milling at 600 revolutions per minute for one hour. Recyclability of catalyst upto eight runs without any significant loss of activity and no use of any hazardous solvent as well as additive make this technique eco-friendly [151]. Although silica and alumina have appreciable holding capacity for metal ions, however the mesoporous silica also have good adsorption capacity for catalytic metal ions due to its uniform pore size and ordered porous framework. Moreover, this regular distribution of pores facilitates easy diffusion of reactants and catalyzation of reaction. According to a research report, mesoporous silica with grafting of Cu(OAc)2 displayed high yield of 1,2,3–triazole at room temperature. Due to high thermal and mechanical stability of this adsorbent, the catalyst can be recovered efficiently and can be recycled [152]. Microporous naturally occurring zeolites also have excellent catalytic activity in CuAAC upon modified with Cu (I) ions [153]. Despite of these, non–porous spinels, CuFe2O4–nanoparticles have been used in aqueous medium at elevated temperature in CuAAC reaction [154]. The nanoparticles of Cu (I) bonded to clay and metallic copper have been found to afford high yield of heterocyclic compounds through CuAAC reaction at room temperature [155] (entries 5–10 in Table 2). 2.3.4 Nanosized magnetic support In the category of solid supports, the nanostructured magnetic material like Fe3O4 in combination with functionally modified biomolecules act as good support to hold metal and metal ions. Copper anchored over these functionalized magnetic nanoparticles illustrated unique efficiency in CuAAC reactions. In 2017, S. Sabaqian and research group synthesized magnetic and cellulose-based material as an inexpensive and biodegradable support to stabilize CuI at the surface. Modification of cellulose was done by reacting cellulose with 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES) in dimethylformamide at 90 °C to get amine functionalization at the surface. Cu (I) ions and Fe3O4 nanoparticles get adsorbed at the surface through amino groups and oxygen atoms as shown in Fig. 12 . This copper supported functionalized cellulose-based magnetic material (Fe3O4-Cellulose-NH2-CuI) has been used as an efficient catalyst in click synthesis of triazoles that could be easily removed from reaction mixture by using an external magnet. The treatment with water and ethylacetate re-generated the catalyst which was reused with nearly same effectiveness as that of the original catalyst [156]. Shaabani et. al research group reported another such type of catalyst formed by modification of casein. Fe3O4-casein composite, a magnetic biosolid to support Cu2O nanoparticles has been found to catalyze one pot three component reaction of alkyne, alkyl halide and sodium azide in aqueous medium. Reaction mixture was stirred at 55ᴼC including a very small amount of catalyst (0.43 mol%) to get the product of cycloaddition with good yield and regioselectivity. The catalyst was recovered by magnetic separation after completion of reaction for reuse [157,158](entries 11–12 in Table 2). 2.3.5 Ionic liquids for Cu (I/II) immobilization Ionic liquids, especially imidazolinium based molecules, have considerable effects on the chemical reactions as catalytic support materials as well as solvents. The ionic liquids have been found to be more effective for Cu-immobilization to catalyze click cycloaddition of terminal alkynes and organic azides to yield 1,4-disubstituted triazoles under benign reaction conditions. For the easy recovery and reusability of catalyst, the heterogeneous catalytic units having immobilized ionic liquids over solid supports like carbonaceous substances and silica nanoparticles have been preferred and observed in few studies [159,160]. Pourjavadi and research group reported the synthesis of an ionic liquid conducted by radical polymerization reaction of N-vinylimidazole and 1,4-bis-(imidazolinium)butane di-functional monomer in methanol and AIBN(Azobisisobutyronitrile) as radical initiator at 70 °C using graphene oxide (GO) as a filler. When soaked in CuSO4 solution, a considerable amount of Cu (II) got loaded over this imidazole based polymeric material having embedded graphene oxide sheets, as shown in Fig. 13 . The optimized conditions for the one pot three component CuAAC reaction of phenylacetylene, sodium azide and benzyl halide involved the use of 1 mol% of supported Cu (II)complex and 10 mol% of sodium ascorbate as reducing agent in water at 50 °C, that yielded 80−96% of triazole [161]. The use of AIBN as radical initiator for copolymerization of N-vinylimidazole with N,N-dimethylenebisacrylamide and 3-methacrylamidopropyltrimethylammonium chloride resulted into a crosslinked polymeric imidazole based ionic liquid. The imidazole units underwent complexation with Cu (II), when treated with CuSO4. This Cu (II) supported polymeric system has been employed as catalyst in CuAAC reaction of phenyl acetylene with benzyl chloride and sodium azide. The use of 0.1 mol% of this catalytic system in combination to 10 mol% of sodium ascorbate provided a very high yield (85–99%) of triazole in t-BuOH/H2O at 55 °C in 4−6 h. The catalytic material was recovered by centrifugation and used successively without any reduction in triazole output as well as turnover frequency [162]. In 2016, M. Tavassoli et.al described the synthesis of immobilized Cu (II) containing ionic liquids on silica nanoparticles [SNIL-Cu (II)]. First step of synthesis involved generation of surface modified silica nanoparticles, that further treated with 1,2-bis(4-pyridylthio)ethane in DMF at 80 °C for 24 h to get silica nanoparticles immobilized ionic liquid. This system then reacted with Cu(OTf)2 in ethanol at 78 °C for 24 h to get Cu (II) supported system as shown in Fig. 14 . This highly stable, active, reusable and solid phase catalyst with high activity in ‘one pot’ click synthesis of 1,4-disubstituted triazoles. A series of triazoles were prepared by using 0.05 mol% of this system with 2 mol% of sodium ascorbate in H2O/PEG 400(1:1) mixture at room temperature with considerable turnout of 75−80% in just 40−45 min using various organic halides, alkynes and sodium azide [163]. 2.4 CuAAC accelerated by external ligands The ligand attached to the metal in the catalyst prevents the oxidation of Cu (I) to Cu (II) owing to their complexation with copper (I). Subsequently, the addition of ligands improves the solubility of catalyst and also facilitates its activity [164]. If applied in aqueous medium, the external ligand acts as base that accelerates the abstraction of terminal proton and promotes the formation of Cu–acetylide ion i.e. increases the rate of reaction. Ligands with donor atoms N, O, P or S are generally employed. Ligands with nitrogen as donor atom represents major category for CuAAC reactions including the molecules from low molecular weight to higher polydentate ligands, as shown in Fig. 15 . The aliphatic amines ligands have been found to increase the rate of reaction more as compared to pyridine-based ligands [165–168] which is attributed to high basic character of aliphatic amines with respect to pyridine. In pyridine, the nitrogen is sp2–hybridized that is more electronegative as compared to sp3–hybridized nitrogen in case of aliphatic amines and lone pair on pyridyl nitrogen has less tendency to abstract proton from terminal alkyne to facilitate the generation of Cu–acetylide as compared to aliphatic amines. Therefore, the acceleration of the rate of reaction is more with aliphatic ligands, but the protection of copper (I) from oxidation to copper (II) is much efficient with pyridine based chelating ligands. The ligands with basic character such as triethylamine (TEA), ethylene diamine, betaine, diisopropylethylamine (DIPEA) etc. tend to increase the stability of copper (I) species to prevent oxidation, but at the same time decreases the yield of product by promoting side reactions like homocoupling of alkyne as well as triazole [169,170]. Among the ligands having tris(triazolylmethyl)amine skeleton, TBTA was the first member to be applied and proved to show powerful stabilization of Cu(I) in t–butanol/water (2:1) mixture. However, TBTA has less solubility in water. To enhance the water solubility of ligands, the hydrophilic substituents were introduced on ligand skeleton e.g. THPTA and BTTAA [171,172]. The acceleration effects of ligands can be well explained by CuAAC mechanism wherein the binuclear copper (I) complex binds to tris(triazolylmethyl)amine based ligands affecting the rate of reaction [173,174]. A research report by S. N. Semenov group described autocatalysis in copper catalyzed azide–alkyne cycloaddition reaction [175]. The product of CuAAC between tripropargylamine and 2–azidoethanol in the presence of copper (II) salt found to accelerate the cycloaddition reaction by coordinating Cu (II) and causing its reduction to Cu(I) as well as by improving the catalytic activity of Cu(I) in cycloaddition step. The product tris(hydroxyethyltriazolylmethyl)amine acts as a ligand for copper(I) catalytic ion and enhances its activity. The kinetic changes of autocatalysis were studied by using different types of alkynes and azide. 2.5 Ultrasound/Microwave assisted CuAAC An uprising fast and energy saving approach for the synthesis of 1,2,3–triazole derivatives corresponds to the use of ultrasound/microwave for CuAAC having wide range of applications in the field of medicinal chemistry and drug discovery [176–179]. In 2007, Sreedhar and Surendra Reddy reported first CuAAC reaction assisted by ultrasound radiations. The reaction was performed by using an alkyne, an organic halide and sodium azide as ‘one pot’ reaction in ultrasonic bath at room temperature using aqueous medium and Cu (I) iodide as catalyst. The reaction yielded 92% product conversion within 30 min [180]. In 2010, Cravotto with his research group described cycloaddition reaction of benzyl azide and phenylacetylene using metallic copper in a solvent mixture of dioxane and water using ultrasound radiations in an experimental setup as shown in Fig. 16 where the reaction yielded 89% of product in 90 min. To catalyze the cycloaddition reaction, the catalytic ion Cu (I) got generated by the redox reaction through ultrasonication between metallic copper used and copper (II) oxide formed at the surface by aerial oxidation. An increase in rate of reaction as well as yield enhancement has been observed when the reaction was performed under ultrasound and microwave radiations simultaneously [181], as shown in Fig. 17 . The catalysis by metallic copper was also applied for generating modifications in cyclodextrins that constitute a versatile group of ligands. Cyclodextrin–triazole derivatives have been synthesized using a trace amount of metallic copper as catalyst in N,N–dimethylformamide (DMF) at elevated temperature, as shown in Fig. 18 . Further extension to this route involved synthesis of imidazolinium–functionalized cyclodextrin–triazole derivative in water under US and μW radiations (Fig. 19 ). The ionic nature of alkyne favored the reaction in aqueous medium. These positively charged triazole based cyclodextrins act as ligands as well as ionic liquids [182,183]. In 2013, Jacob et.al re-investigated the cycloaddition reaction of phenylacetylene and benzylazide, performed by Cravotto’s research group, but with modified catalytic conditions. The use of copper supported over porous glass as catalyst was generated by ultrasonication from copper (II) acetate in aqueous medium, as shown in Fig. 20 . The reaction has an additional advantage that the catalyst has been isolated and reused [184]. In 2015, S. B. Nallapati and group reported the synthesis of olanzapine based 1,2,3–triazole by ultrasound assisted CuAAC, as shown in Fig. 21 . Alkyne derived from olanzapine was subjected to cycloaddition with benzyl azide in MeCN at 25 °C using CuI and DIPEA (N,N–diisopropylethylamine) as catalytic set which resulted into triazole with 89 % yield within just 20 min [185]. The increase in rate of reaction was reported with the addition of DIPEA as an external ligand. The studies prove the remarkable utility of metallic copper and its salts along with external ligands as catalyst in US/μW assisted CuAAC reactions, however the coordination complexes of copper have been reported as highly efficient catalysts in recent past. In 2018, El-Bendary with his research group synthesized a three dimensional supramolecular coordination polymer, [CuI(CN)(phen)2.CuII(CN)2(phen)].5H2O and introduced as catalyst in click cycloaddition reaction of phenylacetylene and p-fluorobenzyl azide in a solvent mixture of dioxane/H2O in 2:1 ratio at room temperature with ultrasonication as shown in Fig. 22 . The desired triazole was obtained in just 10 min with excellent yield of 99% through synergistic action between ultrasonication and mixed valence copper catalyst. The three dimensional structure of catalyst has network of fused six membered rings having cavities and pores inside the molecule that increases the access of reactants and catalyst. Moreover, it increases the activity of catalyst that makes it superior over normal coordination complexes of copper as catalytic materials [186]. 2.6 Cu–Metal organic frameworks (MOF) The non-recoverability of homogeneous catalysts after catalytic action from reaction mixture has diverted the scientific approach towards the use of heterogeneous Cu (I)–catalysts which have high catalytic performance and can be easily separated from product making the path for its reuse [187–189]. In this regard, Cu–MOFs have been found as promising catalysts in CuAAC reactions [190]. In 2015, P. Li. et.al synthesized a Cu-MOF from Cu(OAc)2 using 2,4,6-tri-(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine and sodium 2,6-naphthalene disulfonate. The resultant species was employed for 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition of alkyne and azide to create 1,2,3-triazole with 94% yield under solvent free conditions [191]. The most significant advantage of this protocol is generation of high yield of product with low catalyst loading along with recoverability and reusability of catalyst without any major loss in catalytic activity. In 2018, a highly stable Cu-MOF was synthesized from CuCl2.H2O, polyoxometalate ion [SiW12O40]4− and resorcin[4]arene based ligand in DMF/Ethanol solvent mixture that proved as an excellent reusable catalytic material in click cycloadditon reaction and yielded 99% of triazole in ethanol at 80ᴼC. Catalyst is found to be highly stable in various organic solvents as well as aqueous solution with a wide range of pH(2–12)192. In addition to the excellent recoverability and reusability, these copper loaded metal organic frameworks, also have great contribution towards phase transfer catalysis in CuAAC reaction. Quaternary ammonium salts, the most commonly used phase transfer catalysts, are very effective and have a long history of their use in organic synthesis, but are associated with few inherent weaknesses i.e. difficulty in separation and reusability that limits their scope [193,194]. To address these issues about traditional phase transfer catalysts, scientists started working in the direction to get easily separable solid phase transfer catalysts [195]. In 2017, a solid copper-MOF based phase transfer catalyst having CuI loaded over MOF decorated with n-pentadecylimidazolinium salt was synthesized and applied in sequential one pot CuAAC reaction. The reaction of phenylacetylene with organic halide and sodium azide using CuI loaded MOF in water produced 1,2,3-triazole derivative in excellent amount of 99.7%. The reaction took 2 h to reach to completion by stirring at 80 °C. This CuI loaded MOF is a heterogeneous phase transfer catalyst that could be recovered by centrifugation after completion of reaction for reuse [196]. Different types of catalytic systems in different reaction conditions expressed in report are summarized in Table 3 . 3 Conclusion and future scope The tailored copper (I) catalytic framework for azide–alkyne cycloaddition reaction has handled us with an excellent tool to generate 1,2,3–triazole derivatives. The fine tuning of copper(I) catalytic sources have customized Cu(II) salts to get active state of catalyst that is recoverable. The protection of Cu (I) species from oxidation using bulky groups as ligands have been proved to be efficient catalysts even in small quantity and under ambient reaction conditions. Copper (I) supported over carbonaceous materials, inorganic solids, organic polymers, dendrimers, magnetic materials, metal organic frameworks have the potential to be recycled and therefore have found extensive use in biochemical conjugations. The abundant modification techniques and catalytic systems have extended their choice of use which depends upon nature of reactant, conditions, availability of resources and applicability of product. In spite of the fact CuAAC being highly versatile and efficient technique, the creation of a catalytic system with facile and comprehensive separation is still unexplored. There has been least emphasis on recyclability of the catalyst so as to maximize turn over number. To improve the efficiency of catalytic system, a robust system needs to be developed which can rapidly and selectively produce the triazoles under photocatalytic/microwave/ultrasound conditions with a high turnover frequency. To address the environmental and economic issues, Cu-loaded solid phase transfer catalysts must be generated for one pot CuAAC reaction in aqueous conditions. Ionic liquids immobilized over solid magnetic supports and having multifunctional moieties to hold Cu (I) can be synthesized that work well in this direction and can be separated easily by magnetic separation. Cu-MOFs having potential to act as solid phase transfer catalysts can be explored more. Declaration of Competing Interest There are no conflicts to declare. References [1] H.C. Kolb M.G. Finn K.B. coredata.dc:description: The use of ‘Click Reaction’ for Cu(I) catalyzed azide–alkyne cycloaddition (CuAAC) has emerged as one of the most powerful tools for the synthesis of library of organic molecules having a wide range of applications. The approach is highly stereoselective that involves the formation of 1,4–disubstituted 1,2,3–triazole derivatives by the combination of diverse structural entities in the presence of Cu(I) as catalyst. There are numerous synthetic Cu (I) complexes with different ligands bound in diverse molecular framework with potential to act as catalyst to stitch organic azide to alkyne producing 1,4-di-substituted products. This review emphasizes on those versatile Cu (I) complexes having tailoring capability similar to those available commercially.
coredata.dc:title: Robust and Versatile Cu(I) metal frameworks as potential catalysts for azide-alkyne cycloaddition reactions: Review
